title: Fullstack Cloudflare with React and Vite (Redwood SDK)

rawLines.text: Welcome to Syntax. Today we have a
really interesting guest on to talk
about Redwood SDK. So we had Tom Preston
Warner on I don't know maybe a year year
and a half ago to talk about
RedwoodJS and uh they've done a little
pivot into something called Redwood SDK.
And I'm I'm so excited about this that
it's middle of the night for for Peter
and I just DM'd him. I was like, "You
want to record right now?" And he said,
"Yes, let's do it." So, I'm pretty
excited about it. Welcome, Peter. Thanks
so much for coming on. It's a super
pleasure to be here. I'm also really
excited by you picking up Redwood SDK. I
obviously wanted to spread like
wildfire, and I think it has some great
ideas, but uh I want people to pick them
out, you know, let's chat about them,
figure out what's better. Yeah. So, I I
just spent the last probably hour and a
half going through it. So like I've got
I've got a million questions and my head
space is in it. So the idea with with
Redwood SDK is that it's a what a
framework for building React apps on
Cloudflare. Is that is that give us the
pitch of what it is? Yeah. Yeah. So um
Redwood SDK is a React framework for
Cloudflare. It starts off as a VIT
plug-in uh that then gives you
serverside rendering react server
components with client side hydration
and uh then also realtime capabilities
that are provided by Cloudflare's
durable object objects. Then Cloudflare
is the platform. So what you get from
them is a super fast edge network all
over the world. You get a D1 database.
Uh you get R2 so you can store your
files. You get cues, you get really,
really great abilities to serve images
to the right devices at the right
resolutions. Um, and you basically get
that for $0 a month or Yeah. $5 a month.
When we were coming up with the idea of
what for what Redwood SDK was, I'm from
South Africa, so I live in a in a rural
community in South Africa. There are
2,000 people where I live. And for me,
it was really important that I could
build software that was good for people
in my community and I mean good in terms
of latency. There are very few providers
out there or hosting platforms out there
that have have servers in South Africa
and Cloudflare has them everywhere. I
think they have something like
230 edge networks and you know cloudfare
is a networking company so they really
really know what they're doing when it
comes to making things fast. So yeah.
So, I was I was very excited about this
when I saw it because there's there's a
couple things that I'm like bullish on
right now and and one of them being the
Cloudflare and all of their products.
Um, they've sort of been on on fire
recently releasing like like workers is
really cool, the durable objects is
really cool. Their cues is really neat.
Um, and then of course, like you said,
it's it's relatively affordable um
compared to lots of other options. I
went to to move my own personal website
which is a Reactbased website to wow
Cloudflare and I first moved it to
Nex.js with server components and I
tried to use Open Next.js and it worked
pretty good but we're we're not it
wasn't totally there at the time. So
then I moved it to to Wacku which
deployed great great to to server
Kapotus and that is also based on Vit
because I'm I'm pretty big on Vit as
well. But there's not aside from wacky,
there's not a whole lot of like vit and
react server components out there. So
the fact that this gives us that was was
pretty exciting.
Totally. And you know the thing is we we
first validated that Cloudflare was a
was a good platform for us to target and
then we built the framework from scratch
within Cloudflare's workerd uh runtime.
So we try to make sure that everything
that we are giving you is Cloudfare
native so to speak. Yep. But with the
pluggability of Vit and Vit has just
released or they're busy releasing the
um React server DOM vit plugin which is
the thing that enables uh React server
components. It used to be a Webpack only
thing and we kind of like
shimmed a whole bunch of stuff to make
it work and now it was we we like
deleted 1,400 lines of code when we
replaced it. So the ecosystem is
catching up to React and React server
components specifically in V in VLAN and
uh I think we're the right product at
the right time.
Yeah, another thing I noticed about it
is that it's this is not like a
framework built on top of these
technologies. Um, which maybe maybe
Redwood.js was um but this is more of
like like an SDK. I dare I say an SDK
that works with the tech that you want.
meaning that it's not like you're not
burying all access to all of these
packages that we know and love like like
Prisma or any other OM stuff or any of
the Cloudflare stuff. You are simply you
you import them directly like you like
you normally would, right? Was was that
a intentional decision? That was a
incredibly conscious decision. I don't
know if you've seen this image of um
Elon M Musk's Space X uh where they have
these iterations of the different kinds
of rockets that they're building. Oh
yeah. Yeah. So I was the co-creator of
RedwoodJS and now I'm creating Redwood
SDK. I don't think that there are many
people that have the ability to actually
or have had the opportunity to build a
framework from scratch twice and this is
my second iteration. So I've learned a
lot of lessons from building the first
framework, trying to use it in my own
startup and then now approaching it for
the second framework. One of the things
that I really wanted to make sure that
we did was that we didn't hide anything
away from you. The moment we did that as
a framework, it made support much harder
for us cuz people wanted the
optionality, but it also made it super
hard to understand. So for me, I wanted
to get down to sort of the bare bones of
what makes sense from a request response
model as well as what made sense from
from a type T typecript position. I
didn't want to generate types. I wanted
there to be no magic. And I mean
thinking about this quite deeply about
why we ended up having frameworks that
look the way they look right now. And
I'm talking about
RedwoodJS. Um, we had these things
called that were magic exports.
Essentially, you would we created like a
DSL for interacting with our framework.
You export a special thing named this
special name and it would do something
special within our framework. I think
it's because people were trying to
emulate Rails. Yes, Rails like Ruby is a
language that gives you the ability to
define DSLs like off the bat. So, there
isn't much traceability in Rails. It's
also just like everything somehow works.
some of their imports. I don't know how
exactly they put things together, but
it's incredibly difficult for a newcomer
to understand where the where everything
is linked together in Rails. And you
started seeing that in in many
JavaScript frameworks. So, I wanted to
take that away. One of the things I
appreciate about Jav JavaScript is the
ability to follow where an import is
coming from and where it's being used.
So, I didn't want to hide that from you.
I wanted to make sure you could trace
it. And I think the result is it just
feels so good.
Mhm. It feels so good to be able to just
see where everything is. For example,
anyone
listening, when you want to declare a
new route, you simply just go to your
worker.tsx file and you can like
register just like the old express days.
You can register a regular route that is
simply returning a response. So, um,
I've talked a lot on the show about the
like the standardization of the web and
and very two of the big ones are the
request and the response, right? That's
what fetch is built upon and and so much
of the so much of the modern web is is
built on the request and response. So,
being able to simply just return a
response object or being able to to
return like JSX components which maybe
be pages. So having like explicit access
to that seems really nice. I I think
it's probably a bit more typing is would
that be fair to say a little bit more
setup? Yeah, totally. I mean, we're not
giving you sort of like return a
redirect function or we're saying, hey,
return new response with a redirect
header,
but you can create those yourself. We
just didn't feel that we that's the
surface area that we need to provide
things for you. Um, you know what's
wonderful about request and response is
that if you're interacting with
thirdparty services and you're returning
a response, you can just stream the
request directly back down to the
browser. We've also enabled that uh via
React server components. So you can take
like say for instance you're chatting to
AI, you could send off a request to an
LLM. It can return a response which is
chunked by default. It's thinking, it's
thinking, it's giving you Yeah. bits of
information over time, you can take that
and just return it straight down the
wire into an RSC component and update
the React component. And that feels so
intuitive. You're just like, okay,
there's nothing crazy going on here.
It's the network. I'm dealing with the
network and the browser APIs. I'm just
sort of facilitating it in between. And
a long long time ago, I was a fan of
saying this. most uh web development is
actually just trying to share memory
from one computer to another in a safe
way. Yeah. And if you can make those
easier, if you can facilitate that in a
simple way, it just makes everything
easier. So I think we've done that by
just standardizing and request response,
it feels like everything is possible.
One of my favorite examples is actually
uploading files to to R2, which is
Cloudflare's answer on S3. uh you just
stream it directly from the you take a
file a form data attach a file to it
push it up to the web server the web
server catches the request and streams
it directly into R2 like it's like three
lines of code I don't know if you've
ever had to deal with chunks in a
multi-art foreign data thing sucks yeah
it's terrible it's really bad honestly
it's it's one of the reasons why I I I
love node so much or or or server
JavaScript so much is that uh like node
used to have its or it still has its own
streaming, but then they implemented
regular streaming. And just being able
to use the same streams and request
response on the client and on the server
and is is such a a beautiful way to
live. I'm a big fan. I feel like having
been a web developer for the past 20
years, I feel like this is the golden
age. We are hitting a beautiful space
and time in software development. And
actually, you know, Redwood SDK is a
response to generative AI by programming
LLMs because an LLM or or or an AI agent
will assist you in the decisions you
need to make uh whilst you're building
software, but it will often lead you
down a a rabbit hole. It'll be like,
"All right, you need a database. Here's
Neon, or here's Planet Scale, or here's
this other thing." And yeah, perhaps you
don't know enough in order to make those
decisions. So with Cloudflare, you just
get that all. You just get everything.
Just use the Cloudflare solution. You
don't have to create like a you don't
have to install that service locally.
You don't have to figure out how the API
works. You don't have to create an
account. You don't have to create a give
them your credit card. You don't have to
figure out how to ship it in production.
There are like these taxes that you pay
when you use external services. And you
don't need to do any of that. You just
focus on the software you want to write
rather than the infrastructure that it
runs on. And people are probably saying
right now like well Cloudflare is a
service uh similar similar to Neon. Why
should somebody choose this where it
only runs on on CloudFire? Like it why
can't you make this just like NodeJS or
or server JavaScript agnostic? So for
us, the really interesting part about
building software is putting it in front
of people, getting your idea from start
to finish as quickly as possible through
the gate, and not having to worry about
the infrastructure. To me, you're not
building a product when you're dealing
with that stuff. And that's if you're
someone that resonates with that idea,
you want to build stuff, you want to
ship your ideas as quickly as possible
and not have to worry about the
infrastructure that it's hosted on.
Redwood SDK is probably going to
resonate with you. I
however see Cloudflare as rather as AWS
than I see it as a Versel for instance.
It's a hosting provider. Certainly there
is lock in there and we have to own
that. Cloudflare gives you a lot of
things that a lot of other hosting
providers can't specifically durable
objects and the tight integrations with
all their with all their services. It's
world class. I I'm
unashshamefully in love with Cloudflare.
Yeah. Yeah. Honestly, people give me
heck sometimes. They think I'm like like
taking money from them or something like
that, but like no, I'm I'm just enth I'm
an enthusiastic user, you know? They
don't even they don't even I get free
hosting accounts from everybody and
except for Cloudflare. I pay my own way
on Cloudflare.
So, that that should say something. But
like let's let's talk about like like
database as well. So if you're using D1,
it's a a relational database kind of or
built on top of SQLite. Yeah. So if
you're interacting with that, you're not
using like the Cloudflare SDK. You're
using like what like Prisma or Drizzle
or something like that. What's the
database look like in Redwood SDK? So we
give you a standard starter and for that
standard starter we give you Prisma. So
we decided that that was probably the
best DX that we could that that worked
for us. But you're connecting through
Prisma to D1 and you're just running
standard migrations. Although there are
some problems with Prisma right now when
it comes to migrations. So we've created
scripts that work around that. Uh and
they are addressing it. And Prisma has
some issues with their large binary.
They have this WOM that's almost like a
meg size and they are reducing that.
They're taking that out and they're just
making it pure TypeScript. So at the end
of the day, things are just going to get
better from that perspective. But we
also have a starter where you can just
use Drizzle or any of the RMS that are
your decision or you can just directly
connect to D1 uh as you wish. But you
don't have to use D1 SQL queries. Yeah,
you don't you don't even have to use
that, right? You could connect to
anything. Yeah. And I mean then in that
case, if you're just connecting to
Postgress or MySQL, that's an external
service, then Cloudflare can also help
you make that super fast. They have
these I don't know what I don't know
what that product is called, but they
have uh like a proxy or something. Yeah,
it's called Hyper Hyperdrive, I think.
Uh let me check that. Cloudflare hyper
hyperdrive. Yeah. And what that does is
it it because Cloudflare is like
serverless. I'm using air quotes here.
They don't like when you use that word,
but it will have a fat pipe to your
actual where your database is because
that's that's a big source of latency
for a lot of people where your database
and your code are not in the same spot
or if you have to do connection pooling
and all that those fun things that come
along with. That actually made me think
of something that we do. So we follow
the request response model. So if you're
if you want to log in a user, you create
cookies and that that user data is
stored in something we call a session.
That session is backed up in Redwood SDK
by uh something called a durable object.
So a durable object I actually I don't
think anyone really knows what a durable
object is, but I'm going to describe it
as best as I understand it. A durable
object is basically another compute
instance that lives alongside your
existing compute instance. um but
they're they are logically separated. So
in case of Cloudflare they have this
thing called smart placement where you
can place a durable object closer to the
user and the worker closer to your
database. Uh the result is that it
reduces latency overall and they will
figure that out automatically. Did that
make sense? Yeah. Yeah. Absolutely. Do
they figure out where to put it? Cuz
like a durable object is backed by D1
and that database needs to to live
somewhere, right? And and they will try
to do their best at figuring out where
it will will actually live. We did a
whole show on on durable objects as well
where we uh we distilled it down to like
durable objects are essentially
JavaScript classes that can maintain
state and they don't go away because
that's that's always one of the the
downsides to using serverless when
versus like a longunning thing is that
you don't have memory. You don't have
have places to keep stuff in between
requests because they they spin down.
Such good tick. Yes, I'm I'm a big fan
of uh of durable objects as well. And I
know there's several people working on
like like a open-source version of it,
just kind of cloning the the API. So
that's if anyone's worried about like
lock in with that type of thing. I I
don't think that would be too big of an
issue. That's cool. Middleware. Let's
let's talk about that. So like Redwood
SDK has has like proper middleware
meaning that you can you can step in and
and stop things and set headers and all
that stuff. Totally. Yeah. So the entry
point for your app is a function called
define app. And at the top of that file,
you can define as many pieces of
middleware as you want. And the
middleware is just a piece a function
that gets the request and the context
and you can modify the context or return
a response in there. um and then it gets
handed off to the root handlers and once
it matches a root handler and then we'll
call a request handler. But we have this
concept that we call interruptors. Uh
essentially any route can take an array
of request handlers. So a good example
is uh that you can then use to interrupt
the flow of the of the request. So a
good example is say for instance you
wanted to do authentication. Typically,
you'd have a function that checks if a
user is logged in or they have certain
privileges. Um, and then you'd allow
them to proceed to the page. So, with an
interrupter, you can create this
function is authenticated. You can check
the session to see if they are logged
in. And if they aren't, you just return
a response that says, "Hey, you don't
have permission to do this. You've now
interrupted the request flow." If you
don't do that part, it will proceed to
the next handler and then it will show
you the page. So you can kind of like
take these functions, you can share them
with your codebase, you're like this is
how I check if people are logged in.
It's a single function. Yeah. And what's
really nice about that is you when you
read the code, when you parse the code,
you can see what's happening. Uh you
don't have to like dig into each request
handler and say, "Okay, we're actually
checking if they're authorized and they
have the correct things." It's just this
little nugget that you attach to the
request handler and makes it really easy
to read and share that functionality.
Those are two layers of middleares. One
is like global and the other one is more
per route. Oh, that's that's interesting
because in Nex.js they started with like
a like a global middleware and then they

with either of those. And then the

to have the the full control over that
so talking about full control I like to
say that we give you control over every
bite that passes over the wire and what
I mean by that is that when you render
out some some JSX or you when you return
a React page it's usually mounted in
like a document an HTML document that
has like a add a title, a body, like a
div, things like that. You know, the

just another component and you then give
it to a method called render. So you

can have a different document based on a

a section in your website that was just
blogs. you could remove the client side
hydration from that document and you
would just serve HTML. There would be no
JavaScript going over the wire and then
if you had like an app side to your

side hydration and then you have
interactivity and then you're getting
JavaScript and react and all the stuff
with that. And say for instance you
wanted real time like you had a

something to update consistently or you
wanted people to do multiplayer stuff.
You switch out the client side hydration
with our real time client side
hydration. So you really have the
ability to ship like many multiple apps
within the same worker. And a typical
use case for that is like when you have
a marketing site and the marketing site
has like this button that's meant to
tell you whether you're logged in or not
and then you click that button and
you'll always see it will be like log in
and then it flips and it's like nope you
are logged in. Click this button. Yeah.
So we can just take that away. We just
send HTML down the wire because we know
if you're logged in or not. We handled
it in the request and then you click
that button then all of a sudden you get
in all the JavaScript that you need. Oh.
Um and another use case for that is you
